PostValue.explanation: This is a useful operational/communications update for the EA community: migrating the Opportunities Board to effectivealtruism.org improves UX, maintainability, discoverability, and could modestly increase matching of people to impactful roles (esp. students and early-career folks). However it’s not a foundational or high-stakes claim — if true it helps EA talent flow a bit more efficiently, but nothing about core EA arguments or major strategy depends on it. For general humanity the post is essentially irrelevant — it’s an internal tooling announcement with negligible direct impact on broader global outcomes.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Clarify quality control and inclusion criteria (big omission). Readers will want to know how you decide which listings are allowed, how you prevent scams/low-quality posts, and who moderates. Actionable fixes: add a short summary in the post of the current inclusion/exclusion rules, the moderation workflow (who reviews submissions, turnaround time), and what verification steps you require for organizations (e.g. org email, links to org site, manual checks). If you plan to change criteria, say when and how stakeholders can influence that process.

2) Be explicit about the AI/data-entry automation risks and mitigations. Claiming you’ll use AI to reduce contractor time raises obvious concerns about incorrect or misleading listings. Actionable fixes: state what tasks AI will do vs what will remain human-reviewed, describe accuracy checks, and note fallback/appeal processes if a listing is wrong. If you aren’t sure yet, say so and invite input rather than implying automation is already solving data-quality problems.

3) Give brief context on metrics, sustainability and coordination with other boards. Lines like “second most visited page” sound promising but lack useful context; readers will want to know traffic numbers, ongoing maintenance costs, and whether this duplicates or coordinates with 80k/other job boards. Actionable fixes: include a sentence or two with key metrics (visits/day or week), expected running costs and staffing model, and whether you have a plan to coordinate with 80,000 Hours / other major listings to avoid fragmentation or confusion. If precise numbers aren’t ready, say so and commit to publishing them soon.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: Targets three clear, high-value omissions that bear on trust and safety (inclusion/moderation, AI automation risks, and metrics/coordination). These are plausible ‘own goals’ that could embarrass the team if left vague, and the suggested fixes are concrete and concise (won’t unduly bloat the post). Not a fatal flaw in the announcement, but addressing them would materially improve transparency and reduce legitimate reader concerns.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: No evidence up to my 2024-06 knowledge cutoff of a notable author named Sarah Cheng within the Effective Altruism/rationalist community or as a public figure. The name appears common and could be a private or pseudonymous individual; please supply works or context for a more accurate assessment.

PostClarity.explanation: The post is well-structured and highly comprehensible: it opens with a TL;DR, clear headings, concrete links/calls to action, and a readable overview and plan. It makes its point convincingly and is easy to follow. Weaknesses are minor formatting/footnote oddities, a bit of jargon (e.g. "MVP", "no-code platform", Airtable) and some optional details that could be slightly more concise or consolidated (e.g. backend/technical notes and undecided criteria). Overall clear and effective.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is primarily an organizational/product update (site migration, UX improvements, Slack/Airtable changes, newsletter and promotion plans), which is routine and unsurprising to EA Forum readers. The only mildly novel detail is experimenting with AI to reduce data-entry costs, but that’s an incremental operational tweak rather than a new idea. To the general public this is even less novel — most organisations routinely move/upgrade websites and improve job boards.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: The post presents a clear, plausible case that migrating the Opportunities Board to effectivealtruism.org improves control over UX and is worth modest further investment. It cites some positive signals (the board’s performance in the 2024 EA Survey and being the site’s "second most visited" page) and describes backend improvements and plans, which supports the claim. However, the reasoning relies on relatively weak and anecdotal evidence: key metrics (traffic numbers, conversion rates, user satisfaction, number of placements) aren’t provided, the survey reference is not quantified, and costs/benefits aren’t analyzed. Overall, the argument is reasonable and directionally persuasive but insufficiently supported by concrete empirical evidence.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most major, externally checkable claims are supported: the Opportunities Board is live on effectivealtruism.org and includes the board, a submit page, an FAQs/feedback page, and a bi‑weekly newsletter signup (all publicly visible). The forum history shows CEA/CEA Online Team took stewardship around early 2025, and the 2024 EA Survey report explicitly lists the EA Opportunities Board as a named source for recent cohorts — supporting the author’s claim that the board performed relatively well in that survey. However, several operational/internal claims in the post ("already the second most visited page on effectivealtruism.org", the exact details of the Airtable migration and Slack-integration technical changes, and experiments using AI to reduce contractor data-entry time) are internal metrics or work-in-progress claims that are not verifiable from public pages. Because most user-facing claims are verifiable but internal metrics/operations are not, I rate the post as well-supported overall but not fully externally validated.
